comments.body: @fabiob Thanks for following the existing style.
Please do not use optional parameters in callbacks as discussed [here](http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/declaration-files/do-s-and-don-ts.html).

Please correct me if I am wrong - but I think this is not applicable in this case.

You *definitely can* call the done()-callback without supplying a error parameter (signaling that everything was OK). It is exactly the special case mentioned in the docs: done() might be invoked with one or zero arguments.

The done()-callback is not even provided by the user but the framework itself.
You're correct, I missed the extra level of parameter nesting. Sorry for the confusion.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +629,633 @@     * Defines a pre hook for the document.
     */
    pre(method: string, parallel: boolean, fn: (next: (err?: NativeError) => void, done: (err?: NativeError) => void) => void,
      errorCb?: (err: Error) => void): this;
    pre(method: string, fn: (next: (err?: NativeError) => void) => void,

comments.body:
I think there are more options that can be added here as well, however I wasn't able to find it after a (very quick) search on Google and the MongoDB docs.

Perhaps we should extract that into an interface instead and see if we can find a full list of options?

The link provided here is dead, it seems: http://mongoosejs.com/docs/2.7.x/docs/schema-options.html
I believe this is the documentation/options available for the `safe` option: https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/write-concern/index.html
This returns a `Promise` now (or `null`).
Oh my bad, this is fine. I got confused because I thought "pseudo-promise wrapper" referred to `MongooseThenable`, which was deprecated.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +75,79 @@   * Opens the default mongoose connection.
   * Options passed take precedence over options included in connection strings.
   * @returns pseudo-promise wrapper around this
   */
  export function connect(uris: string, options: ConnectionOptions, callback: (err: mongodb.MongoError) => void): null;

comments.body: `numAffected` is still there: http://mongoosejs.com/docs/api.html#document_Document-save
Their migration doc states that numAffected is no longer passed: https://github.com/Automattic/mongoose/blob/master/migrating_to_5.md#numaffected-and-save
Oh you're totally right. This is fine. I'll make a PR to update their API docs.
Can you return `this` to be consistent with other methods?
It's semantics at this point. `this` refers to the same object, whereas here we're returning a whole new one.

Oh okay, my thinking was that returning `Schema` returns the base `Schema` class. If we clone, we could be cloning on an interface that extends the base `Schema` class, so returning `this` would be more accurate.

I think returning `this` means returning the same interface that `clone()` was called on rather than returning the same `object` like in normal code.
How come these are required when the fields in `ValidateOpts` are optional?
See `ValidateOpts` discuttion above

Can be simplified to:
```ts
aggregate(aggregations: any[], cb?: (err: any, res: any[]) => void): Promise<any[]>;
```
Based on: http://mongoosejs.com/docs/api.html#aggregate_aggregate
Oops! Misread the return type lol
Remove this unless you want to help maintain these definitions. 🙂
I actually would like to help maintaining some defintitions, so I will leave it in.
Okay great!
@DanielRosenwasser Yeah, but Connection actually doesn't have `Promise.prototype.finally` on it. (The Mongoose code manually attaches only `then` and `catch`.)
Do you want to help maintain the mongoose type definitions and be notified of every PR? If not, remove this line.

I did added myself just because of that, since MongoDB 4.0 upgrade will need more work for Mongoose (and also the related typing packages), so I want to give a helping hand on reviewing the changes. And most probably I might be doing the updates myself as well. Thanks for asking! :-)
Thank you for your support!
Could you add a test or two that covers these function signature changes?
Sorry, im new to this repo - do you mean mongoose code, or testing the typings?
does 8d6981d8ada94d745a8941438a8d01661e776fab do what you asked?
Yes, that's exactly it!
should i rename "value" to "tiedValue" because that would be the name in the code, but "[value]" is used in the jsdoc
It's probably fine as-is? Presumably people are going to consult the documentation before reading the actual implementation code.

Shouldn't it be `lean(bool?: boolean | object): Query<T> & QueryHelpers;` ? (without the 1st `<T>`)
This seems to make all results `unknown` right now.

Edit: never mind, my version doesn't seem to work either, but this one still seems wrong.

Yes of course. It is semantically more correct than type `any`.  Also `unknown` is type-safe counterpart of `any`. If you want to save the type `any`, you can modify it this way 
` lean<T=any>`. The default behavior will be like type `any`
Indeed but what I meant is we do have the type, lean could be correctly (or as correctly as can be) typed instead of returning unknown.
Can you add a test for instantiating `Document?
added
